The Cabinet had before them the following bills, whioh had already been considered by theCabinet Coal Committee:-isiaticnvipuserence:inet 39)( Con-sion 5.)Coal Minesours) Bill,36.Miningus try11, 1926.The Coal Mines (Honrs) Bill, 1926(Paper C.P.-247 (26)):The Mining Industry Bill, 1926(Paper CP.-248 (26)) ,together with typewritten amend-ments circulated shortly before. the Meeting of the Cabinet.The former Bill provides that during the next five years an eight-hours day can be worked in mines in cases where the owners and miners agree.The latter Bill makes provision for the re-organisation of the coal-mining industry by amalga-mation and absorption schemes (Part I); for workingfacilities (Part II); for an additional royaltieslevy of 5 per cent, and its application to welfare and for the provision therefrom of pit baths anddrying accommodation (Part III); for restriction of Indiscriminate recruitment for the mining industry(Part IV); for coal mines excess payments and coallevy (Part V) .The Cabinet were informed that these Billswere required as a matter of urgency in order to implement simultaneously the undertakings containedin the Prime Minister's statement in the House ofCommons on June 15th. in regard to the suspension ofthe seven hours limitation and those of the recom-mendations in the Report of the Royal Commissionon the Coal Ind\istry which the Government had decidedto adopt and which required legislation. The pro-posed National Wages Board had not been included as it was bitterly opposed both by owners and miners,and it was proposed to deal with the question later, - after further consideration and consultation with both parties .As regards the Government's coal policy as awhole, there were various proposals of the Commissionoutstanding, including Prof it-Sharing, Pit CommitteesSelling Agencies, and Transfer Prices, on some ofwhich it was Intended, as soon as circumstancespermitted, to set up Committees with which miners and mine-owners might he associated.
